France faces record number of homeless children as school year begins
subhead: The seventh annual barometer conducted by UNICEF France and the Federation of Solidarity Actors found that 2,159 children were left without shelter on the night of August 18, even after their families had managed to reach the emergency housing hotline.

title: In Kyiv, Oleksandr Glyadelov's images defy the bombs
subhead: The Donbas, the Maidan Revolution, Bucha… For 35 years, Ukrainian photographer Oleksandr Glyadelov has documented the history of his country. Starting September 5, the Ukrainian House in Kyiv will present a major retrospective of his work. The exhibition pays tribute to the spirit of national resistance.

title: Conditions for scholarship students in France continue to worsen: 'We work, we get assistance, but we're still poor'
subhead: In Nanterre, just outside Paris, students who receive a scholarship from the state describe starting the new academic year amid rising living costs.

title: Mohammed VI, the makhzen and the art of palace secrecy
subhead: 'The Enigma of Mohammed VI' (5/6). In order to maintain his power, the Moroccan monarch relies on a handful of loyal supporters, most of whom he has known for decades. However, internal rivalries betray a certain nervousness, revealing the uncertainty surrounding the future of his reign.
byline: By Christophe Ayad and Frédéric Bobin

Mohammed VI, a king with big foreign policy plans
subhead: 'The Enigma of Mohammed VI' (4/6). In recent years, the Moroccan monarch has become highly active on the international stage. From the highly sensitive issue of Western Sahara to Morocco's rapprochement with Israel, he has often established himself as the central player.
byline: By Christophe Ayad and Frédéric Bobin

title: Life in the West Bank settlement of Kedem Arava: 'We're not taking anyone's place, there is only sand around us'
subhead: Established in 2017 near the Jordanian border, the Kedem Arava settlement contains prefabricated homes housing some 60 families, former city dwellers seeking a life closer to nature. While most residents deny ideological motivation, their presence fully aligns with the annexation of Palestinian territory sought by the Israeli far right.

title: Jacques Rancière, philosopher: 'Today, the people fueled by resentment manufactured by billionaires dominate the public sphere'
subhead: 'May '68 Thinkers Reflect On Trump Era' (1/6). The philosopher of emancipation examines the roots of the current reactionary offensive. He views contemporary utopian micro-communities as new ways of 'living as equals.'
